6.009 Practice Quiz 3B -- Fall 2018

Please download the .zip file below, which contains all the files, test cases, etc., you need to complete the quiz using your own machine. When unzipped it will create its own directory with the quiz's files. The instructions follow below. You'll be editing quiz.py to add the code requested by the instructions.

Download: q3_practice_b.zip

Submission

When you have tested your code sufficiently on your own machine, submit your modified quiz.py below by clicking on "Choose File", then clicking the Submit button to send the file to the 6.009 server. To receive credit you must upload your code before the timer expires.

The server will run the tests and report back the results below but be aware that the server may be backlogged at the end of the quiz session. Once the server has indicated that your submission is queued to be checked, you're all set -- your submission has been accepted as on time and you don't need to wait for the results to be reported.

Tests must complete within the server timeout to receive credit.

 No file selected

Instructions

This quiz assumes you have Python 3.5 (or a later version) installed on your machine.

This quiz is closed-book and closed-Internet -- you are only allowed to access the quiz page on the 6.009 website and the material provided in the .zip file. You are not allowed to access other information on your laptop or on the web. You may not discuss the quiz with other students -- even after you complete the quiz and/or complete any regrade submission -- until regrades have been completed for all students and final quiz grades assigned (at the end of next week), because many students will still be working on regrades or other/conflict offerings of the quiz.

When you unzip the .zip file, you'll find library.pdf, which includes the chapters 1-4 of the Python Library Reference -- they cover the built-in functions (Chap. 2) and built-in data types (Chap. 4). Note that Python's built-in help function will provide a concise summary of built-in operations on data types (e.g., help(set)) or information about the arguments for the built-in functions (e.g., help(sorted)).

Proctors will be available to answer administrative questions and clarify specifications of coding problems, but they should not be relied on for coding help.

As in the labs, test.py can be used to test your code in quiz.py. Each of the three problems has a unit test: TestProblem1, TestProblem2, etc. Remember that you can run tests for a specific problem like so

python3 test.py TestProblem1

This quiz is worth 20 points; these points will ultimately translate to an equivalent grade (equivalent GPA score) for the quiz per the 6.009 grading policy published on the home site. Your quiz points score will be based primarily on performance of your last code submitted during the quiz, tested against some number of test cases for each problem. However, points will also be lost in other circumstances:

  • You must not not import any Python modules to use as part of your solutions -- quizzes with import statements (or their equivalent!) will be given grades of 0.

  • Having your code check for a specific input (called "hard coding") and then return a specific result is okay only for the base cases in iteration or recursion. Problem solutions that look for specific test case arguments other than base cases are disallowed and will receive no credit.

  • You do not have to include doctests or detailed comments in your code: we will not deduct any points for lack of comments, but encourage those as general good practice.

Aside from these special point deductions above, your quiz score will be based on the number of points your last submitted code earns across all problems on the quiz. For each problem, if you pass all of the tests for that problem, you will receive the full base points for the problem (e.g., 5 points if the problem is a 5 point problem). If you pass 8 of 10 test cases for the problem, you'll receive 80% of the base credit for that problem; thus, for a problem worth 5 points, your points for that problem would be 4.0. The number of points each problem is worth is indicated at the start of the problem description below. Note also that to pass some of the tests within the server timeout allotted, your solution may have to be reasonably efficient.

For your own debugging, you are welcome to add test cases of your own to test.py (but note that any tests you add will not be run on the server).

Problem 1. all_simple_paths (7 points)

In this problem, we consider directed cyclical graphs. These graphs are represented as nodes with a given label; each node may have zero or more edges directed from that node to other labeled nodes in the graph. A node is represented as a key in a graph dictionary; the set of edges directed out of that node to other nodes is the value associated with the node in the dictionary.

For example, the following code (graph1) and picture represent the same graph.

graph1 = {'a': {'b', 'c'},
          'b': {'a', 'b', 'f'},
          'c': {'c'},
          'd': {'e', 'd', 'c'},
          'e': {},
          'f': {'a'},
         }

A path is represented as a tuple of node labels, e.g., path1 = ('a', 'b', 'f') is the path from node 'a' to node 'b' to node 'f' in the graph, consisting of valid edges connecting one node to the next in the path. The path ('d', 'f') is not a valid path, because there is no edge from node 'd' to node 'f'.

A simple path is a path that does not contain the same node label more than once. For example, in the graph above, ('a', 'c') is a simple path, but ('a', 'b', 'f', 'a', 'c') is not a simple path (because it contains node 'a' more than once).

We desire a function all_simple_paths(graph, start_node, end_node) that returns the set of all simple paths starting at the given start_node and ending at the given end_node in the given graph.

Examples:

  • all_simple_paths(graph1, 'e', 'f')) returns set()
  • all_simple_paths(graph1, 'a', 'c') returns {('a', 'c')}
  • all_simple_paths(graph1, 'b', 'c') returns {('b', 'a', 'c'), ('b', 'f', 'a', 'c')}

Problem 2. weeBay (7 points)

We seek to implement a small e-commerce marketplace (weeBay) that helps make deals between buyers and sellers of items.

The basic idea is to match offers of buyers and sellers. We will represent offers as instances of the item class Item which have two attributes:

  • price, the maximum value a buyer is willing to pay for the item for instances representing a buying offer, or the minimum value a seller is willing to sell their item for for instances representing sell offers, respectively
  • owner, the name of the person in search for the item or the name of the current owner of the item, for instances representing buy or sell offers, respectively

We will represent weeBay as an instance of the Market class which you should modify so that it can process transactions of items between customers. Your task is to implement two methods for this class, offer_to_buy and offer_to_sell, both of which find the best matching offer in the market and return the sold item (the sell offer) with the owner updated to match its new owner and the price updated to reflect the price for which it actually sold.

If no matching offer exists, each of these methods should return None, and weeBay should keep track of this offer to make an optimal match at the time of subsequent buy or sell offers.

Like in real life, a specific offer should never be matched twice (for instance, if you offer an item for sale, it is only bought once, and if you offer to buy one item, you only buy it once unless you make a second offer). An offer to buy and an offer to sell can be matched if the price of the offer to sell is less than or equal to the price of the offer to buy. Given an offer to buy, the best selling offer to it is the one that has the lowest selling price out of all the existing ones. Analogously, given an offer to sell, the best matching buy offer is the one with the highest price at the time.

Additionally, whenever a customer makes an offer, they specify what kind of item they are selling or buying in different levels of specificity by instantiating different subclasses of Item. A selling offer and a buying offer are matched and the sale is possible if the item sold is an instance of the class of the item being looked for to buy (i.e., if the item for sale "is a kind of" or is_a_kind_of the item desired to be bought).

Below is an example of a set of different types of objects. Arrows in the figure indicate "is-a" (also known as "is-a-subclass-of") relationships.

Annotated Example 1

>>> m = Market()
>>> a = Vehicle('Anne', 100)
>>> sold = m.offer_to_sell(a)
>>> sold is None   # no existing offers to buy, so no sale takes place
True

>>> sold = m.offer_to_buy(Vehicle('Bob', 90))
>>> sold is None   # Bob's price is too low; Anne won't sell
True

>>> sold = m.offer_to_buy(Vehicle('Carl', 110))
>>> # Carl's price is above Anne's asking price.
>>> sold  # Best deal for Carl is to buy at Anne's asking price
<Vehicle, Carl, 100>
>>> a     # Note that item a has mutated to be owned by Carl, bought for 100
<Vehicle, Carl, 100>

>>> sold = m.offer_to_sell(Vehicle('Dan', 85))
>>> # Dan offers to sell, at a price below Bob's max buy price
>>> sold  # Dan's get deal is to sell to Bob, at Bob's max buy price
<Vehicle, Bob, 90>

Annotated Example 2

>>> m = Market()
>>> a = Vehicle('Anne', 100)
>>> m.offer_to_sell(a)

>>> sold = m.offer_to_buy(Truck('Carl', 110))
>>> sold is None  # Anne's Vehicle may not be a Truck, so Carl won't buy
True
>>> sold = m.offer_to_sell(F150('Erik', 125))
>>> sold   # Erik's F150 Truck costs more than Carl is willing to pay

>>> sold = m.offer_to_buy(Truck('Fiona', 150))
>>> sold   # Fiona is willing to buy any truck, so buys Erik's
<F150, Fiona, 125>

>>> sold = m.offer_to_buy(Truck('Fiona', 150))
>>> sold   # Fiona wants another truck. But there are no more for sale for 150 or less

>>> sold = m.offer_to_sell(Ram('Greg', 35))
>>> sold   # Greg is willing to sell a beat-up Ram Truck. Fiona still wants one, so buys Greg's
<Ram, Fiona, 150>

Problem 3. word_squares (6 points)

We are interested in finding "word squares" containing words of length n. A valid word square, as shown in the two examples in the figure below, is a tuple of length 4 with four unique (different) words ordered as (top, right, bottom, left), where the overlapping letters in the corners of the square contain the same letter. Note that words are always read left to right, or top to bottom (like in a crossword puzzle). The word square corresponding to the left square in the figure below is ('food', 'door', 'tour', 'fast') and the word square on the right with words of length 3 is ('yak', 'ken', 'son', 'yes'). Another valid word square (not shown) is ('ad', 'do', 'so', 'as'), in that case containing words of length 2. Note that ('go', 'on', 'on', 'go') is not a valid word square, because the same word appears more than once in the tuple.

Write a generator word_squares that takes a top word, and generates all valid word squares containing that top word. You are provided with a set allwords that contains all words in English. Note that to pass some of the tests, your implementation will need to be fast enough to complete that test within a timeout on the server.

Some examples are shown below:

  • word_squares('is') returns <generator object word_squares at SOME_MEMORY_LOCATION>
  • set(word_squares('is')) returns {('is', 'so', 'to', 'it'), ('is', 'so', 'no', 'in')}
  • len(set(word_squares('is'))) returns 2
  • len(set(word_squares('at'))) returns 3
  • list(word_squares('notaword')) returns []
  • list(word_squares('go')) returns []
  • len(list(word_squares('bar'))) returns 1743

The timeouts on the server for test_01 through test_06 are 5, 5, 15, 15, 20, and 30 seconds, respectively.
